Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Diagnosing the Timing and Drivers of Northeastern Caribbean Holocene Droughts with Sinkhole Lake Records
Award.AbstractNarration:
This century, 80% of the world could face insufficient water necessary for food production, energy and national security, human health, and ecosystems. The United Nations estimates that Caribbean losses related to climate change by 2080 will be $11.2B, with $3.8B from drought. Rainfall in the Caribbean and American southeast is linked to similar ocean and atmospheric factors. However, geologic records of rainfall document extreme Caribbean megadroughts lasting tens to hundreds of years over the last several millennia. This project aims to identify and communicate the causes and drivers of these megadroughts through research and teaching American students at 3 institutions. It will help the United States, developing nations, and small island nations mitigate future water security risks.

Climate model forecasts of rainfall changes in the American southeast and Caribbean for this century are currently equivocal, and available paleoclimate archives from the Caribbean document extreme megadroughts with a severity not observed in the instrumental era. These droughts were apparently not uniform across the Caribbean, and their causes remain poorly understood. Here, the investigators propose to develop a network of long-term rainfall records from key portions of the northern Caribbean using established geologic techniques and state-of-the-art climate modeling to diagnose the climatic drivers of Caribbean droughts.

This award is cofunded by the Paleo Perspectives on Climate Change Program and the Office of International Science and Engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many small island nations in the Caribbean have limited freshwater storage capacity and thus are susceptible to changes in rainfall patterns. The Bahamas contain many sinkholes or lakes, whose sediments are promising archives from which to discover evidence for past climate. Here, we use a combination of information from the waxy coating on plant leaves, and from the pollen of the same plants. Each can be found when studying the sediments of sinkholes, and each can help to reveal the history of rainfall.

The plants growing adjacent to inland sinkholes commonly include pines, palms and hardwoods. Plants take up rainwater through their roots and their leaves record of the isotopic composition of past rainfall. In more coastal settings, mangroves may also grow if there is seawater influence. A prime concern for the study of plant waxes in sinkholes, is the possible influence of mangroves, because of the seawater rather than rainwater that they drink.

We detect the presence of mangroves by the pollen that they release, and this can be separated from the pollen from other non-salt tolerant plants in the vegetation community. We use the proportion of mangrove pollen, as a simple guide to the size of the necessary correction. We can cross examine this with other unique molecular clues for mangrove presence as well. In this way we have been able to remove the mangrove effect from the plant wax record.

Our pollen-corrected plant wax reconstructions of past rainfall isotopic compositions are within the range of modern observations, even when mangroves are present. We thus have confidence that we have excluded most of the mangrove effect. We can now use plant waxes in sinkholes to detect past shifts in rainfall with wet or dry periods spanning decades. We generate such records over several thousand years of mud cored from the bottom of sinkholes.

We further compare to climate model experiments to find out what these rainfall isotope shifts mean for the climate system. We find isotopes follow large scale circulation patterns which tend to promote or discourage rainfall across a broad region. We thus find a regional signal of climate change, from plant molecules in the bottom of sinkholes.

The research has involved collaborations across several states, and at USC centered on rigorous laboratory analytical biogeochemistry training of graduate and undergraduate researchers, with faculty engagement with high school researchers via the Palos Verdes Unified School District high school science fair.
